title: Classic Gardening Clubs & Culture
description: Remember garden clubs, seed catalogs, and victory gardens? Test your vintage gardening knowledge!

questions.question: What were 'Victory Gardens' that millions of Americans planted during the 1940s?
options: Gardens planted to celebrate military victories
Flower gardens planted for returning soldiers
Home vegetable gardens to supplement food rations during WWII

questions.question: Which seed catalog, with its colorful illustrations, was eagerly awaited each winter by gardeners across America?
What popular flower, bred in countless varieties with names like 'Peace' and 'Mr. Lincoln,' was the pride of many garden club members?
What was a common activity at garden club meetings besides discussing plants?
options: Arranging flowers for competitions and community events

questions.question: Which iconic gardening tool brand, known for its red-handled tools, was a fixture in American gardens?
What was the popular practice of preserving homegrown vegetables by sealing them in glass jars called?
Which vegetable was the most commonly grown crop in American home gardens for decades?
What type of garden event, held at churches, schools, and community centers, let gardeners buy and trade plants?
options: A plant swap or garden sale

questions.question: Which popular lawn product, first sold in 1928, helped homeowners grow thick, green grass?
What did gardeners call the practice of cutting back plants in fall or early spring to encourage new growth?
Which flower bulbs, planted in fall for spring blooms, were a highlight of garden club programs each year?
What large annual event, held in cities like Philadelphia and Chicago, showcased elaborate garden displays and won awards?
What natural material did gardeners spread around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds?
Which organization, with chapters across the country, was the primary social club for women gardeners from the 1920s onward?
options: The National Garden Club (Garden Club of America)

questions.question: What did gardeners traditionally use an Almanac, like the Old Farmer's Almanac, for?
options: Planning planting dates based on frost dates and moon phases
